entry.title: æ‰©å±•/bootåˆ†åŒº
entry.content:
how to expend the capicity of /boot partition in linux

  1. use the Disks offered in the System to build a partition for new /boot, and click â€œMount the filesystemâ€ signed by a triangle icon
  2. copy all the things form old /boot partition to new /boot partition . new /boot partition willbe mounted in /mnt
  3. click the old /boot prtition in Disks, click buttons as following
  • â€œMore actionsâ€ signed by a gear
  • â€œEdit Mount Optionsâ€¦â€, meanwhile, wtrite the config down for later
  • uncheck â€œMount at Startupâ€
  • modify â€œMount Pointâ€ to something else, such as â€œ/boot_oldâ€
  • and click OK
  1. click the old /boot prtition in Disks, and â€œUnmount the filesystemâ€. click buttons as following
  • â€œMore actionsâ€ signed by a gear, and click â€œEdit Partitionâ€ modify â€œTypeâ€ to linux filesystem and Change
  • â€œEdit Mount Optionsâ€¦â€ copy the config form old one
    = OK
  1. and now it can work almost, but there is something broken likely.to solve this , you can use the Boot Repair. here is its brochure:

installation Boot Repair

  1. Recommended repair

  • launch Boot-Repair from either :

  • the Dash (the Ubuntu logo at the top-left of the screen)

  • or by typing â€˜boot-repairâ€™ in a terminal

  • Then click the â€œRecommended repairâ€ button. When repair is finished, note the URL (paste.ubuntu.com/XXXXX) that appeared on a paper, then reboot and check if you recovered access to your OSs.

  • If the repair did not succeed, indicate the URL to people who help you by email or forum.

  • if you have trouble in booting, if you computer is booted by grub2, here is you solutions:

    • ls
    • find the boot file location
    • set root = (hd0, gpt0)
      (hd0,gpt0) is your boot file location
    • linux /path/to/your/bootfile(vmlinuz*) root=/dev/sda0
    • /dev/sda0 is your root location
    • initrd /path/to/your/bootfile(initrd*)
    • boot

now you can boot your computer.
